entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (3/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

The previous two episodes have demonstrated how to create and register a custom mass processing function code in COHV as well as have provided an outline of the actual implementation of the mass processing. However, the implementation has not done anything useful, yet.

Now, it is the time to add some meat to the implementation and dive into more advanced topics like test mode, function parametrization and order updates.

 

Test mode

Let us start with test mode. Typically, SAP standard mass processing functions provide a test mode option that runs all data processing without actually saving any changes or updates. That is particularly useful if you want to test a mass processing run without committing the updates.
Figure 1 Test mode on

Figure 2 Test mode off

The implementation of the mass processing function does not need to explicitly handle test mode operation, i.e. either to rollback or commit changes. That is done by COHV backbone. Make sure to test thoroughly if the test mode is used to make sure that the custom mass processing function is compatible with the test mode handling in COHV. If you are not sure, the rule of thumb is not to use the test mode.

 

Passing parameters to the mass processing function

Mass processing functions can be supplied with additional parameters. That is often used in SAP standard functions, and it can be enabled for custom ones.

First, additional parameters need to be added to the transparent table and the dialog structure that have been created in the episode 2. Make sure to add the same fields of the same type to the table and to the structure.
Figure 3 The transparent table with a parameter

Figure 4 The dialog structure with a parameter

Once that is done, the parameter will appear in COHV.
Figure 6 The function's parameter in COHV

 

Mass processing logic implementation

Now, let’s implement the mass processing logic to update production orders. My goal is to change production orders quantity by the value passed with the function parameter. The implementation goes into Z_CO_WORK999_EXEX_SINGLE function. Refer to the previous episode for the details of the function creation.
Figure 7 A snippet of the mass processing logic implementation

Here is the entire implementation of the custom mass processing logic, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Get a production order number from LS_COWBPAR-OBJNR
  2. Read the order’s header details with the BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL function
  3. Modify the order quantity by the value of the function parameter. It is available in the LS_COWBPAR-QTYCHANGE field
  4. Update the order with the BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE function
*** BEGIN custom mass processing logic
   DATA:
     prodord    TYPE cowrk_s_prodord_mask,
     return     TYPE bapiret2,
     headers    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_order_header1,
     orderdata  TYPE bapi_pp_order_change,
     orderdatax TYPE bapi_pp_order_changex,
     dummy      TYPE string.
 
  prodord = ls_cowbpar-objnr.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL'
     EXPORTING
       number        = prodord-aufnr
       order_objects = VALUE bapi_pp_order_objects( header = abap_true )
     TABLES
       header        = headers.
 
  READ TABLE headers INDEX 1 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<header>).
   orderdata-quantity = <header>-target_quantity + ls_cowbpar-qtychange.
   orderdatax-quantity = abap_true.
 
  CLEAR return.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE'
     EXPORTING
       number     = prodord-aufnr
       orderdata  = orderdata
       orderdatax = orderdatax
     IMPORTING
       return     = return.
 
  IF return IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE s100(co) WITH prodord-aufnr INTO dummy.
   ELSE.
     MESSAGE ID return-id TYPE return-type NUMBER return-number
     WITH return-message_v1 return-message_v2 return-message_v3 return-message_v4
     INTO dummy.
   ENDIF.
 
  ls_context-aufnr = ls_exec_obj-aufnr.
   CALL FUNCTION 'CO_APPLLOG_WRITE_SYMSG'
     EXPORTING
       i_loghandle           = ls_appllog-log_handle
       i_syst                = syst
       is_context            = ls_context
     EXCEPTIONS
       application_log_error = 1
       OTHERS                = 2.
 *** END custom mass processing logic

entry.title: Supply Protection and Other Methods in aATP
entry.content:
In advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP), customers have different options to optimize the availability of articles or products. Supply protection (SUP) is one of these methods, which is integrated into other processes in aATP. 
Sometimes it’s not clear how supply protection works with other methods and how to differentiate to other methods. The methods have a lot in common, like the usage of a characteristics catalog. But there are also differences regarding the use cases, the usage in a process, and there are pros and cons for every method. 

Let’s look at different aspects of the integration of supply protection into the following processes in aATP: 

  • Product Availability Check (PAC) 
  • Product Allocation (PAL) 
  • Backorder Processing (BOP) 
  • Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC) 
  • Supply Assignment (aRUN) 

Link:

SAP Help: Integration into other Processes

Supply Protection and Product Availability Check (PAC) 

Planned supply protection is relevant for the product availability check (PAC), which determines whether a demand (for example, from a sales order) can be confirmed. The product availability check compares the request of the sales order with the available stock for the related material. Within this logic, there is also a check if there is supply protection available for the relevant combination of material and planning level. If yes, the system calculates the restricted quantities and reduces the available stock for the sales document. If this reduced quantity is not sufficient to meet the request, the sales document will not be (fully) confirmed for the requested delivery date. Supply protection also reduces the available stock after the replenishment lead time (RLT). However, the availability check is calculated with infinity stock. The restrictions defined by supply protection don’t have an impact after the RLT.  

Whether supply protection is considered in the product availability check depends on the settings for the scope of the availability check. Only if supply protection is activated in the scope of check for the related checking rule, will PAC consider supply protection. For more information, see  How to Activate Supply Protection. 

As supply protection is integrated in the basic method of the product availability check, the impact of supply protection when creating a sales document is also shown in the Review Availability Check Result app, as part of the intermediate results of the check. For more information, see  Supply Protection in Review Availability Check Result. 

The following illustration shows how supply protection reduces the availability by adding virtual demands:

Supply Protection within the Product Availability Check

Supply Protection and Product Allocation (PAL) 

Several use cases can be addressed with product allocation or with supply protection; and sometimes they can even be used in combination. Logically, the product allocation check is performed before the availability is checked. Therefore, PAL can limit the request which is checked in PAC (together with SUP). 

What are the differences between Product Allocation and Supply Protection? 

With the sales product allocation check, it is possible to define an upper limit for a group. A matching demand can’t get a higher confirmation compared to the limit defined in product allocation. As the sales PAL is checked in advance of the product availability check, the allocation ignores the availability situation. A demand which is limited by PAC can’t get more quantity, even if there is no shortage. In case of a shortage situation, a demand within the defined allocation can get the quantities if the stock is available, and if the PAL limit isn’t exceeded. This leads to the issue that another requested quantity can’t get confirmation although there is a matching PAL quantity. 

Supply Protection and Product Allocation
Supply protection is integrated in the product availability check and considers the availability situation. It adds virtual demands so that the availability is reduced, depending on whether the demand matches a supply protection object or not. If there is a lot of supply compared to the protected quantities, supply protection doesn’t have an impact on sales. 

Can Supply Protection and Product Allocation be Used as Complementary Methods? 

Yes, with supply protection, minimum quantities can be defined. With this, it can be ensured that even in shortage situations important groups can get some quantities. With product allocation, limits can be defined, which prevent a group from taking too much quantity and not leaving enough for others. 

However, there is a risk of a wrong setup, where product allocation prevents the consumption of quantities protected by supply protection, and vice versa. This is the case when, for example, supply protection with high priority exists for a key customer, and there’s also a product allocation object matching the demands of this key customer. If the product allocation is already consumed, this customer can’t order more quantity. In this case, consumption of protected quantities in supply protection isn’t possible, and other demands are restricted by this. 

Advantages of Supply Protection 
Allows different settings of restrictions, but will not limit demands, if there is enough stock/supply. 

Advantages of Product Allocation 
Can be set up also on more generic levels (not only a specific material-plant combination), which requires less maintenance. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Best Practices for Supply Protection – Using Supply Protection and Product Allocation 

Supply Protection and Backorder Processing (BOP) 

With backorder processing, it is possible to recheck orders with specific rules so that orders which have been confirmed may lose their confirmation while others can now get confirmed. With BOP, it’s possible to reallocate available stock to competing sales orders, allowing customers to prioritize some orders ("winners") over others ("losers"). 

This seems to be close to the idea of supply protection. However, the logic of BOP is to reopen sales documents and change the sequence. A winner is processed first and has a rule to get a better result. A loser will come later and has a rule that the result can be worse. 

Links:  

SAP Help: Backorder Processing (CA-ATP-BOP) 

How does Supply Protection work together with BOP? 

While processing backorders, supply protection is checked as well. The consumption of protected quantities in supply protection will get removed temporarily, and the orders which are processed first are also checked against supply protection. The result will be different, but it considers the restrictions of supply protection. 

Naturally, it wouldn’t make sense to set up protection groups with high priority for demands which should be “losers”, according to the defined logic for BOP. 

Supply Protection and Alternative Base Confirmation (ABC) 

With ABC, it is possible to define alternative options for supply by exchanging a product and/or a plant. Depending on the rules for ABC, a demand for product A could be replaced by product B, which is not the same but treated as a good substitute. 

From the perspective of supply protection, this is always a new, independent check. The reason is quite simple: product and plant are keys for supply protection. If a product is exchanged by another product, the check for supply protection will search for matches and calculate restrictions for a different material-plant-combination. 

In this case, there won’t be a consumption for the originally matching supply protection object. For the second check, consumption might be written. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Alternative Base Confirmation (CA-ATP-ABC) 

Supply Protection and Supply Assignment (ARun) 

Supply assignment ensures that the supply is assigned to the orders according to the changing requirements. Supply protection is only a virtual demand and doesn’t have a direct relationship to supply elements. Quantities which are assigned via supply assignment are not considered as available quantities in PAC. Settings in supply assignment can be used to respect or overrule restrictions defined by Supply Protection. 

Links: 

  • Community Blog: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment(ARun) 
  • SAP Help: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment 

Related Links: 

  • SAP Community Blog: Supply Protection in a Nutshell  
  • FAQ-Document: 3141787 - FAQ - Supply Protection (SUP) with advanced ATP

entry.title: S/4 Procurement for Public Sector: Purchasing Profiles: A Concise Overview
entry.content:
What Is a Purchasing Profile?

A Purchasing Profile is a structured container of organizational, accounting, and process data assigned to purchasing personas (purchaser, requestor, contracting officer). It centralizes shared attributes so users do not repeatedly search, re-enter, or manually maintain foundational data. It also isolates role-relevant information, reducing noise in day-to-day tasks.

Why It Matters

Without profiles, every purchasing action (request, order, contract) requires manual selection of entities like company code, cost center, purchasing org. data, or accounting information. Profiles let the system derive these automatically, letting users focus on true differentiators (item, supplier choice, terms).

Key Personas

  • Purchaser: Executes ordering.
  • Requestor: Initiates demand; minimal commercial adjustment.
  • Contracting Officer: Manages contractual frameworks and compliance.

A business configurator (or administrator) sets up profiles centrally instead of each persona maintaining their own settings.

How Profiles Work

Each profile bundles attributes (organizational units, accounting defaults, category controls, workflow indicators). These are referenced when creating purchasing objects (purchase requisitions, orders, contracts). Missing values can be overridden only where necessary.

Core Benefits

  • Reduced data entry and errors
  • Faster document creation
  • Consistent compliance posture
  • Centralized maintenance
  • Clear separation of role context

Inheritance Model

Profiles support hierarchical inheritance: child profiles extend parent attributes. This reduces duplication:

  • Define common data once (e.g., legal entity, currency).
  • Specialize at lower levels (e.g., category restrictions).
    Attributes can be:
  • Excluded: explicitly removed so they do not propagate further.
  • Overridden: replaced with a new value.
  • Marked as default: preferred value when multiple candidates exist.

Exclusions and Defaults

Exclusion flags stop an attribute from flowing down the inheritance chain. Default flags resolve ambiguity when more than one candidate attribute could apply.

Flexible Hierarchy

No rigid tree structure is imposed. You can design a model aligned to:

  • Geography
  • Business unit
  • Spend category
  • Project or program
    This flexibility supports gradual evolution without full redesign.

Implementation Tips

  1. Inventory common purchasing data elements.
  2. Start with a base (global) profile.
  3. Add layers only where differentiation is justified.
  4. Use exclusions sparingly; prefer consolidation.
  5. Audit default flags to avoid silent conflicts.
  6. Document profile intent for each layer.

Summary

Purchasing Profiles streamline creation of purchasing documents by centralizing and inheriting key data across personas. They reduce maintenance effort, improve consistency, and allow flexible structuring without enforcing a rigid hierarchy. Proper setup enables purchasing users to concentrate on value-added decisions rather than repetitive data handling.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit: Adapt the XML file to your business needs
entry.content:
When using the staging approach for your data migration, you often face the challenge that the provided XML file contains sheets and columns within the sheets that are not relevant for your business needs.

Did you know that it is possible to adjust the XML files easily?

However, before I go to the possible options, note that you must be careful when deleting, as any change can corrupt the XML structure. There is also no guarantee that such a tailored XML file can still be used after upgrading to a higher release.

After creating a migration project in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit using the Migrate Your Data app select Download Template in Action for a specific migration object and choose File Type → XML file.

Note 

The description below is for Microsoft Excel. The procedure may differ when using another spreadsheet program than Microsoft Excel.

Option 1: Delete a non-mandatory sheet

Open the downloaded file and choose Enable Editing button. Select a non-mandatory sheet you want to delete – choose the context menu by clicking on your mouse and choose "Delete".

 Confirm on the follow up pop-up you want to delete.

Proceed in this way with all the non-mandatory sheets that you want to delete.

Note

You can only delete non-mandatory sheets and delete sheets even though the worksheet contains mandatory columns. This is because there is no need to fill the mandatory columns in the sheet with data if the sheet itself is not relevant for your project.

Option 2:  Delete a non-mandatory column within a sheet

First, you need to unprotect the sheet. So, you need to select a sheet where you want to delete one column or more columns – choose the context menu by clicking right on your mouse and select “Unprotect Sheet”.

Select the column(s) you want to delete – in my example all columns for Tax Calculation Brazil. Choose "Delete".

Note

Alternatively, you can go to File → Info → Protect Workbook area and click on Unprotect for the sheets you want to make changes on.

Save your changes. You can now fill your XML file as usual and load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit.

When you upload your data, the tool informs you that the Validation Completed with Warnings.  

To be able to view the messages, choose "Show Messages" you get a list of all messages occurred during Validation.

In this case, warnings are displayed because the fields deleted in the previous steps are missing from the sheet. 

 To load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit select your file and transfer the data via Actions → Transfer Data to Staging Tables.

 The instances will be loaded into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit staging tables.

You can now proceed with your data migration steps as usual.

 Using CSV files

Like the XML file, you can easily tailor your CSV files  as you only need to use the files for the structures and fields you want to process. Just provide the files for mandatory structures and the structures you need. Within the files you must also only provide the mandatory fields and the fields you need. All the other fields you can remove.  A CSV file has much less administrative data than an XML file. The 100 MB limit is the same, but with tailored CSV files the http-protocol related size limit is not reached that fast as using XML files.

entry.title: What’s new in DTV 1.7
entry.content:
DTV 1.7 is now released and generally available for SAP customers. In this blog you will find the new features available in the latest DTV release

Enhanced pre-delivered content

Pre-delivered content has been enhanced with additional SAP reports and transactions. Below are the additional SAP reports and transactions which are now supported with the new release.

You can also check SAP Note:  3258383 - DTV : SAP Pre- delivered Content

Validation support for transparent tables

With the latest release of DTV (DTV 1.7), the tool now supports validation of standard database transparent tables and custom transparent tables. You can find the Tables tab in the test specification screen as highlighted below.

Mass upload of custom reports and custom name space reports

With the latest DTV 1.7 release customers can now perform mass upload of custom and custom name space reports at one go using the option Add Multiple (highlighted in the below screen shot)

Runtime Analysis - statistics information related to DTV can be sent to SAP

With the new release DTV 1.7, customer can send runtime statistics to SAP using the feature “Runtime Analysis”

Integration enhancements for Lean SDT using BTC scenario

In DTV 1.7 release, integration of DTV with lean SDT using Business Transformation Center (BTC) scenario is enhanced with following 

Upon selecting Use DTV Tool option while creating the cycle in BTC

  • Automatic creation of DTV project in source and target system happens
  • Project global data filled with the time slice data automatically
  • Automatic import of certain business reports for validation in the test specification screen

DTV related useful links and SAP Notes

  • SAP Note 3117879 – Central SAP Note for DTV
  • 3657674 – DTV 1.7 Delivery Note
  • Help Documentation – Data Transition Validation
  • Business data validation using DTV tool - Blog post
  • Best practices to follow during DTV implementation
  • Work Item Level Execution in DTV

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Replacing SAP Fiori apps during system conversion
entry.content:
SAP Fiori is the primary user experience of SAP S/4HANA.

So if you are already using SAP Fiori in the classic SAP Business Suite, the degree of change in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA can come as a surprise. The uplift in SAP Fiori can add an extra unexpected challenge to your system conversion.  In this post you will learn which decisions are needed and gain some suggestions on how to resolve them.

Hint: The classic SAP Business Suite includes SAP ECC, SAP Suite on HANA, SAP Simple Finance, SAP SRM, SAP GRC, and other solutions running on SAP NetWeaver.

These suggestions are collated from experiences of myself and my colleagues in the Early Adopter Care program for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and our SAP Customer Services & Delivery colleagues.

From our experiences across system conversion customers worldwide who are already using SAP Fiori in classic SAP Business Suite. These customers usually:

  •  Have deployed a limited number of SAP Fiori apps - usually less than 100 apps - in their classic SAP Business Suite environment. 
  • May be using SAP Fiori in a hybrid mode. For example, using SAP Fiori for employee self-service and manager self-service apps, and some targeted mobile apps, while SAP GUI is used for daily on-system tasks.
  • Want to take bring quick wins (aka immediate ROI) from the new/improved SAP Fiori launchpad features, and from the huge amount of predefined launchpad content available in SAP S/4HANA. 
  • Even where the strategy is to move all users to the central launchpad – i.e. SAP Fiori launchpad in SAP Build Work Zone – you still need your local launchpad – i.e. SAP Fiori launchpad available on-stack in SAP S/4HANA – deployed as well.  The local launchpad is the target for content federation, and gives you access on-stack configuration, administration apps, and clean core extension apps.  Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core.

First the good news: Your change management journey is easier. 

Even though the SAP Fiori launchpad has changed, your users will recognize:

  • the overall look and feel of the launchpad,
  • some of the main launchpad features such as Settings, Search, and Notifications
  • know generally how to work with tiles, links and apps.

Your target user experience: the SAP Fiori launchpad My Home page as it appears in SAP S/4HANA 2025.

Now for the work ahead!

Start by listing all your existing SAP Fiori apps, custom-built apps, partner-built apps, and any custom-built launchpad features.  A simple spreadsheet will do.

Hint: Do your best to capture the SAP Fiori app id for apps delivered by SAP.  You can use the app id to find successor apps.

When doing a system conversion to SAP S/4HANA:

  • You will need to decide which of your existing apps and launchpad features to retain, replace, or discard. 
  • You may need to adjust custom-built apps and custom-built launchpad features, such as launchpad plug-ins.
  • This includes partner-built apps and launchpad features that you are using.

In this blog post you will learn:

  • Replace your predefined SAP Fiori apps with successors
  • Retain your custom-built Fiori apps
  • Verify partner-built Fiori apps you have deployed
  • Review your launchpad feature usage for successors
  • Remember your administrators
  • Watchpoints when coming from SAP Fiori in Enterprise Portal
  • Reintroducing your upgraded launchpad to your business users
  • Learnings to get you started
  • Background information: What’s behind the changes in SAP Fiori

Replace your predefined SAP Fiori apps with successors

Expect that most of the predefined SAP Fiori apps you are using in SAP Business Suite (SAP ECC) will need to be replaced.

Of the 836 SAP Fiori apps provided for the classic SAP Business Suite, only 248 of these are supported in SAP S/4HANA 2025. That’s less than 30%. Of those 248 apps:

  • 3 apps are deprecated and should not be used
  • 20 apps are available with successor, so you should use the successor
  • 11 are reuse apps that provide sub-features and are not available as tiles
  • 27 are industry-specific (mostly IS-OIL and IS-HER) and not relevant to most customers
  • 69 are relevant only to SAP GRC
  • 12 are relevant to SAP HCM compatibility pack – and are replaced by successors when moving to SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA

Leaving only 106 apps generally available, or about 12% of apps.

Hint: You can test this for yourself in the SAP Fiori apps reference library, downloading your list of apps and running them through the Upgrade Impact Analysis against your target SAP S/4HANA release. Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Impact Analysis.

At most customers, the only app that is retained is SAP Fiori app F0862 My Inbox.

Hint: If you are currently using app F0862 My Inbox, you should consider with your system conversion:

  • Adding SAP Fiori app F6511 My Outbox to all users who have My Inbox.  My Outbox is a predefined app in SAP S/4HANA that reuses the same configuration as My Inbox. My Outbox provides self-service answers such as: Where is that workflow now? Who is the next approver? Is that workflow complete?
  • You may also want to consider adding the unified inbox across cloud solutions - SAP Task Center - which can be deployed with SAP Build Work Zone on desktop, and with SAP Mobile Start on mobile devices.

Most other apps will need to be replaced by successors.

 

General advice about successor apps

Sometimes there are obvious successors.

  • Successor apps can look and behave very differently to your current app. You will need to deploy the successor app to explore it.
  • Successor apps often have improved clean core compliant extension options. You will need to learn clean core techniques, such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, and Adapt UI.
  • If you have extended your existing SAP Fiori app, you will need to review your extensions, decide if the extensions are still needed, and if needed, reapply them using clean core compliant techniques.

Sometimes there are no successors.

For example, where the functionality has been moved to a SAP Cloud solution.

Where there are no successors, you will need to consider your options, such as:

  • Deploy the successor SAP Cloud solution
  • Replace with a custom-built app
  • Revert to a classic UI – such as SAP GUI, Web Dynpro application, or WebClient UI

Hint: If the classic UI works but is simply too busy for your users, or missing some defaults / tips, you can make some easy improvements with SAP Screen Personas. SAP Screen Personas is the Adapt UI for classic GUI transactions. There is no additional subscription needed for SAP Screen Personas. SAP Screen Personas flavors can be easily applied to existing launchpad content using the Launchpad App Manager – Adaptation Mode to add the parameter for the Personas Flavor.

Refer to:

  • SAP Help – SAP Screen Personas
  • How to use SAP Screen Personas with SAP Fiori Launchpad
  • SAP Fiori app F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas

Example of Adapt UI for SAP GUI transactions in the SAP Fiori launchpad as it appears in SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 : 

Adapt UI for GUI Transactions in SAP S/4HANA 2025 launches SAP Screen Personas flavor maintenance for the app

 

How to find Successor Apps

These are predictable patterns you can use:

  1. Review Related Apps in the SAP Fiori apps reference library
  2. Approve apps become My Inbox sub apps
  3. HCM apps move to SAP SuccessFactors and/or SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA
  4. SRM apps move to Ariba or to Procurement
  5. Smart Business apps move from HANA Live to ABAP CDS Views
  6. Predictive Model apps move to Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM)
  7. Factsheet apps move to SAP Fiori elements Object Page

 

1.   Review Related Apps in the SAP Fiori apps reference library

Check the Related Apps tab. In some cases, the successors apps are listed.

You may need check if there are already successor apps for the successors.

Hint: Use the most recent app for your SAP S/4HANA release.

 

2.    Approve apps become My Inbox sub apps

These are usually easy enough to find. All of them also require the main app F0862 My Inbox to be deployed. Examples:

App ID

App in SAP ECC

App ID

Successor app or feature in SAP S/4HANA

F0400

F0544

My Inbox - Approve Travel Requests

 

3.   HCM apps move to SAP SuccessFactors or SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA

If you are moving to SAP SuccessFactors, you should review alternatives in the relevant solution. For example, employee self-services apps in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.

You should also check for related options to unify the User Interface where you can. For example SAP Help – SuccessFactors Employee Central Integration - Introduction to SAP S∕4HANA UI Integration with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

If you are moving to SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA, your existing apps move across to SAP S/4HANA. These are usually easy to find.

Examples:

App id 

App in SAP ECC

 App id

Successor app or feature in SAP S/4HANA

F3074

My Timesheet (Version 3/Fiori 2.0)

F3074A

My Timesheet (S/4HANA / Version 4)

F1311My Leave Requests (Version 2)F1311AMy Leave Requests (Version 3/Fiori 2.0)
F3596Start Process

F8225

My Processes (S/4HANA)

F3646Process Inbox (Fiori 2.0)F8289Process Inbox (S/4HANA / Version 2)

If you are using SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA in tandem, you should review the new integration options:

  • S/4HANA My Timesheet v4 powered by SAP SuccessFactors Time Management ( - Successor for CATS)
  • An implementation guide to S/4HANA My Timesheet v4 powered by SAP SuccessFactors Time Management
  • SAP Note 3586566 - Adjusting Input Fields Position in Create Assignment in My Timesheet (S/4HANA / Version 4) Fiori app

Hint: Some SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition customers who are planning their move to SAP SuccessFactors are taking a tactical approach to retain existing versions of SAP Fiori apps for HCM.  As an interim approach, they keep the Compatibility Pack for HCM to avoid the move to HCM for SAP S/4HANA.  

 

4.   SRM apps move to SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass or to Procurement

Start by reading this important reference blog post from SAP: SAP S/4HANA Procurement – Considerations for customers with SAP SRM. This blog post gives an overview of the extended roadmap. 

If you are considering keeping a standalone SAP SRM in tandem with your SAP S/4HANA solution, you should also check the central SAP Note 2611066 - SAP SRM and S/4HANA for the latest information on the roadmap.  

Most SRM self-service apps move to SAP Ariba Guided Buying.

Supplier-focused apps move to other solutions such as SAP Ariba Network.

You can find the apps in SAP Ariba in the SAP Fiori apps reference library using the main filter SAP Fiori apps on SAP BTP.

SAP Fiori apps library main filters highlighting the filter SAP Fiori apps on SAP BTP

Then use the sub-filter which is the SAP Ariba product name

SAP Fiori apps library subfilters of SAP Fiori apps on SAP BTP highlight the apps in the SAP Ariba solutions

Examples of successor apps in SAP Ariba:

App ID

App in SAP ECC

App ID

Successor app in SAP Ariba

F0406

Track Shopping Carts

F7624

My Purchase Requests

F0407

F6784

F0408

Approve Shopping Carts

F7599

My Inbox - Buying

 

There are a few apps that stay with Procurement in SAP S/4HANA. For example, confirmations are processed in SAP S/4HANA.

App ID

App in SAP ECC

App ID

Successor app in SAP S/4HANA

F2707

Approve Confirmations (SRM)

F5039

F1824

F4489

F0383

Purchase Order (SRM)

F7117

Display Purchase Order

 

5.   Smart Business apps move from HANA Live to ABAP CDS Views

Smart Business apps were introduced for SAP Business Suite on HANA. In that solution, many of these apps were based on HANA Live Views. HANA Live Views were largely superseded by ABAP CDS Views for improved lifecycle management. 

Most of these apps were reissued for SAP S/4HANA with the backend coding changed to be based on ABAP CDS Views.  

The successors of Smart Business Apps are easy to find.

Examples:

App ID

App in SAP Business Suite on HANA

App ID

Successor app in SAP S/4HANA

F0513

Cash Flow Analysis

F0513A

Actual Cash Flow

F0574

Contract Expiry

F0574

Contract Expiry

F0685

Cash Discount Forecast (sFIN)

F1735

Cash Discount Forecast (S/4HANA)

 

The tools to adjust, extend, or copy these KPIs have changed.  This means you will also need to deploy these apps from the SAP Business Role Analytics Specialist (SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST). 

 

App ID

App name in SAP S/4HANA

F2814

Manage KPIs and Reports

F1572A

Custom Analytical Queries and Services

F2170

View Browser

F2595A

Manage Date Functions (Version 2)

 

6.   Predictive Model apps move to Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM)

These apps were used for early steps into Machine Learning. With the rise of generative AI, the new apps are critical tools for re-/training, activating, and monitoring models exchanged between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business AI.

These are:

App ID

App in SAP Business Suite on HANA

App ID

Successor app in SAP S/4HANA

F2033

Predictive Scenarios

F4469

Intelligent Scenarios

F1837

Configure the Consumption of Predictive Models

F4470

Intelligent Scenario Management

 

7.   Factsheet apps move to SAP Fiori elements Object Pages

The early Factsheet apps were mostly built for SAP Business Suite on HANA. Most of these were quite simple. Most were display only.

Compare the supplier fact sheet in SAP Suite on HANA

Supplier object page in SAP Business Suite on HANA supports only a limited view of supplier data and has few extension options

With the current F0354 Supplier object page from SAP S/4HANA 2025

Supplier object page in SAP S/4HANA 2025 shows many tabs and fields and can be adjusted with Adapt UI

The new object pages offer a much more capable summary of a single object, with:

  • Support for actions
  • Support for long texts and attachments
  • Optional AI-assisted features, such as AI-assisted Smart Summarization***

Hint: ***AI-assisted Smart Summarization is a base feature in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. For SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition, it is one of several AI features in planning to be made available with upcoming SAP S/4HANA 2025 feature pack stacks. For the latest information, refer to the What’s New Viewer for SAP S/4HANA 2025.

Object pages can be standalone, but are more often part of a Manage app, based on the SAP Fiori elements floorplan List Report.Examples:

App ID

App in SAP Business Suite on HANA

App ID

Successor app in SAP S/4HANA

F0348

Purchase Order

F0348A

Purchase Order (Version 2)

F0046

Customer

F0046A

Customer Master FactSheets

F0354

Supplier

F0354

Supplier

F0128

Fixed Asset (ERP)

F3425

Manage Fixed Assets (New)

F1626

Fixed Asset (sFIN)

F3425

Manage Fixed Assets (New)

F0731

Manage G/L Account Master Data

F0731A

Manage G/L Account Master Data (Version 2)

F1628

Journal Entry (sFIN)

F0717A

Manage Journal Entries - New Version

F0123

Cost Center (ERP)

F1443A

Manage Cost Centers (Version 2)

F1623

Cost Center (sFIN)

F1443A

Manage Cost Centers (Version 2)

 

Retain your custom-built apps

This is a tactical approach. Most custom-built apps based on SAP Fiori design and development models will convert relatively easily as classic SAP Fiori programming models are still supported in SAP S/4HANA. This includes custom-built sub-apps for tasks in SAP Fiori F0862 My Inbox.

Important: Supported means that the apps will technically still work. However, these classic techniques have several disadvantages compared to the latest techniques to support Enterprise-ready apps.  Refer to UI5 Demo Kit documentation -  Enterprise Features of SAPUI5.  Classic programming techniques usually require more effort to upgrade, are NOT considered Clean Core, and are NOT recommended for building new apps!

Refer to SAP Note 3578329 - Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility

You will need to review your custom-built apps for:

  • Frontend (SAPUI5) coding – you will need to check for any adjustments needed due to the change in SAPUI5 version.  You should refer to the advice in UI5 Demo Kit – Read Me First – Upgrading .  You should consider verifying your apps using the SAPUI5 legacy-free version as explained in Explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free
  • Backend coding – You will need to check if any database tables you update still exist, and if the OData V2 services you are using require any changes. These coding changes are typically covered by your custom code migration. 

Hint: In your SAP S/4HANA solution you can activate the on-stack Custom Code Migration apps to make cleaning your apps easier during/after system conversion:

  • F3191 Custom Code Migration

You need to prepare your business users for mandatory changes in your custom-built apps:

  • On system conversion, custom-built apps using the SAP Fiori elements floorplans are automatically upgraded to the latest version of the floorplan.
  • Usually this is a positive change as it makes it easier for your business users to adopt new apps in SAP S/4HANA – especially Manage apps, Monitor apps, and Overview page app, and they get automatic benefits such as personsalization, Export, and Share features included with their apps.

 

If you decide to replace a custom-built or partner-built app that is currently coded as a SAPUI5 freestyle app, you should:

  • Update your programming practices to SAP Best Practices.
  • Consider moving custom-built apps to SAP Fiori elements for faster development and greater consistency for business users
  • Review the advanced extension options with the Flexible Programming Model Explorer – these help you avoid creating a freestyle app … keeping your overall solution consistent
  • Consider applying SAPUI5 Flexibility Services – to minimize future changes.

Explore the new SAPU5 legacy-free version to check the app against best practices

If you are intending to use SAP Build Work Zone, you may also want to consider whether you deploy your custom-built apps to the ABAP Platform of SAP S/4HANA, or to SAP BTP.  If your app uses any SAP BTP services, or integrates with non-SAP data or components, you should consider deploying to SAP BTP. 

 

Verify your partner-built apps and features

It is critical that you check with your partner whether your existing partner-built app or launchpad feature (e.g. launchpad plug-in) will also work for SAP S/4HANA.

Important: Do this early as it may impact your commercial arrangements with your partner.

If the apps and features are part of partner product you can refer to SAP Note 3634480 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 : Compatible Partner Products

Hint: For on-premise customers refer to SAP Note 3654390 - SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition 2025: Compatible partner products

Where your partners were employed software developers who have custom-built apps for you, you may need them to review the front-end and back-end coding of their apps.

The same guidelines apply as for your self-developed custom-built apps.

 

Review your launchpad feature usage for successors

Many apps – including custom-built apps – rely on launchpad features to work. For a system conversion customer, the main features to review based on your existing usage are:

  • Themes
  • Navigation
  • Search
  • Notifications
  • User Settings
  • Custom-built launchpad plug-ins

You can speed up reviewing launchpad features by running a workshop with your business and technical stakeholders. 

The SAP Activate roadmaps for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition contain many UX Adoption accelerators, including the workshop template UX Adoption_ UX Strategy and Guiding Principles Workshop. This workshop template shows how to quickly present and capture Yes/No/Defer decisions on many launchpad features and common app features. 

There are several quick win features that you should consider including in your new launchpad configuration on SAP S/4HANA:

  • My Home for SAP S/4HANA – This is a very attractive home page for business users. It already includes AI-assisted options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, which are planned to be made available to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (timing to be decided – on current planning most likely a later FPS of SAP S/4HANA 2025 release). When using the central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone, you can retain My Home for business users by using the federation option content exposure version 2.  Refer to: User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise), SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Organizing your My Home page, and SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Simplifying My Home Activation from SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 or higher
  • Context-sensitive Help – can be provided with SAP WalkMe digital adoption platform, or if you are an existing SAP EnableNow customer you can integrate with SAP EnableNow.
  • App Support – self-service troubleshooting which captures error logs. This replaces transactions SU53 for identifying missing authorizations and so much more! Refer to blog post SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – New improvements in App Support
  • Manage News / Display News – for news announcements. Next generation of transaction SM02. Refer to Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release Minimum release is SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0, minimum SAPUI5 version is 1.136.5.  You are recommended to patch up to the latest available SAPUI5 patch level.
  • MS Teams integration – for collaboration and as a step towards working with Microsoft CoPilot. Refer to SAP Help - SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition - Integration - Integration with Microsoft Teams

 

Themes

If you applied custom themes you will need to rebuild them, as they will no longer be compatible with the SAPUI5 version of your target SAP S/4HANA release.  Refer to UI5 Demo Kit – Read Me First - Supported Combinations of Themes and Libraries.

You should consider alternatives to avoid theme maintenance wherever possible.

For example, instead of using custom themes to highlight your Development or QAS environment, configure the System Information Bar.  This configured via Launchpad Configuration Parameters.

Refer to Learning  video Configuring the SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA

You can also use Launchpad configuration parameters to:

  • Replace the logo
  • Set an alternative accessible text (tooltip) for the logo

If you do need to rebuild your themes, maximize your custom themes working life across future upgrades by making sure you rebuild on the latest SAP Theme family, which is currently Horizon (sap_horizon, sap_horizon_dark, sap_horizon_hcw, sap_horizon_hcd). 

You will need to use the tool UI Theme Designer – which is provided as part of your SAP S/4HANA environment.  Within the UI Theme Designer, focus on using the Quick, Detailed, or Expert options.

Important: Avoid direct CSS changes. Across many project experiences, CSS changes to themes have the highest risk of introducing undesirable side-effects and have been known to break the standard behaviours of apps and features. For further advice, refer to UI5 Demo Kit – Essentials – Theming.

 

Navigation

Navigation around the launchpad moves from Groups to Spaces and Pages. Groups are deprecated. Spaces and pages bring:

  • Improved performance
  • Improved personalization – on the page and on the My Home page
  • Better support for complex roles through merging of spaces, merging of pages, and automatic hiding of unauthorized tiles/spaces/pages
  • Easier change management – as the space/page menu reinforces the major processes and activities of the role
  • Easier WYSIWYG layout maintenance through the SAP Fiori apps F4834 Manage Launchpad Spaces and F4512 Manage Launchpad Pages.

Hint: Spaces and pages also offer more site choices when using the central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone.

A conversion to SAP S/4HANA is often the easiest time to move from Groups to Spaces and Pages, because you only have a few existing apps to move across.

A starter option is to migrate your current groups to pages using the tool Create Launchpad Pages from Groups (transaction /UI2/FLP_GTP).

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Migrating from groups to spaces and pages - Why, When, and Key Differences for Users
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – How to migrate from groups to spaces and pages

Screenshot of the tool Create Launchpad Pages from Groups

 

Enterprise Search

More than 350 search models are provided.   

Classic index-based searches on the TREX or BWA are moved to the SAP HANA database. New searches based on CDS Views are added. You can use either all searches or only the CDS View based searches. In SAP S/4HANA 2025 there are now more CDS View-based search models than classic models.

Refer to SAP Help – Enterprise Search – Configuration Guide.

You can find all the search models via transactions ESH_DASHBOARD or ESH_COCKPIT.

You will want to deploy the SAP Fiori app (use predecessor app F3036 in releases SAP S/4HANA 2023 and below).  You can use this app to:

  • Review the status of CDS View search models.
  • Edit CDS View search models delivered by SAP
  • You can create your own custom search models based on CDS Views (SAP defined or custom-built in ADT).

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - How to find Enterprise Search connectors for SAP Fiori applications
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA –Limit Search Object Access in Fiori Launchpad made easier

 

Notifications

Notifications are used far more widely in SAP S/4HANA that they were in SAP Business Suite. They extend across workflow, situations, process-specific notifications, smart business KPIs, and more.

  • Sending notifications by email is still possible but not encouraged.  
  • Notifications can be federated to the central launchpad in SAP Build Work Zone.
  • Push notifications are supported when using SAP Mobile Start (requires SAP Build Work Zone).

Refer to

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Workflow, Situation Handling, KPIs, etc
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Impact on Business Users
  • SAP Help – ABAP Platform - SAP Fiori launchpad - User Guide – Using the Launchpad - Working with Notifications.

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Where and how to configure
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Which notification to use when – Notifications for Admins and Developers

Notifications can be integrated to Microsoft Teams

  • SAP Help – ABAP Platform – SAP Fiori launchpad – User Guide – Working with Notifications Integrated into Microsoft Teams

 

User Settings

User Settings have improved with each release.   

Default Values are effectively the self-service replacement for Set/Get Parameters. For most customers, their main concern is the use of Default Values compared to classic Get/Set Parameters.  For this refer to the following blog posts:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Synchronizing Default Values with Set/Get Parameters
  • Applying User Defaults in SAP S/4HANA

Default values includes options for key users to set up default value combinations for their teams. Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Yes Key Users can set Default Values for other Users.

 

Custom-built Launchpad plug-ins

Where possible replace custom plug-ins with similar standard features.  This reduces on-going maintenance effort/cost & minimizes upgrade impacts.  For example, replace a plug-in to show the system/client in the shell header with the standard System Information Bar.

Where you want to retain custom plug-ins, refer to the latest advice in the SAP Help SAP Fiori launchpad > Developer Guide > Extending the Launchpad.

 

Remember your administrators

Many administration tools for your technical team require SAP Fiori apps, so make sure you are including their needs in your assessment.

Several SAP Business Roles are provided as starting points. For example:

  • Administrator (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR)
  • Extensibility Specialist (SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC)
  • Fiori Foundation Administration role generated by the task list SAP_FIORI_FOUNDATION_S4 task list task “Generate Fiori Foundation roles”.

Hint: By default the Fiori Foundation Administration role is a composite role with the id Z_FIORI_FOUNDATION_ADMIN.

There are major shifts to be aware of in:

  1. app activation
  2. launchpad content and layout maintenance

App Activation

To minimize effort, avoid activating apps one by one!  The SAP Fiori rapid activation process is long-established and has been improved over several releases.  It provides support for efficient activation of apps by SAP Business Role, by custom business role, and by business catalog. 

  • For SAP Business Roles it makes exploration simpler by supporting generation of test users, and assignment of existing users. It provides pre-/post- activation prerequisites for special roles.
  • For custom business roles,  it simplifies authorization maintenance for security administrators by generating authorizations based on content assignments and SU24 authorizations defaults for app services. Hint: You can control which assignments are generated via the Launchpad Configuration Parameters.
  • For business catalogs - the smallest grouping of apps - you can respect the segregation of duties within the technical team.  Catalog activation is also integrated into the Launchpad Content Manager (Client-Specific) for ease of managing delta changes.

For an introduction refer to: 

  • SAP Help - SAP Fiori Overview - Rapid Activation of SAP Fiori 
  • SAP Note 2902673 - Rapid Activation for SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA - Overview
  • You will find further resources in the section Learnings to get you started.

Example process to activate apps by catalog respecting Segregation of Duties across the technical team

 

 

Launchpad content and layout management

Intent-based navigation works as before. That is an intent consists of a logical Semantic Object + Action pair, that can flexibly be used to point to any UI content supported by the SAP Fiori launchpad.

However, there have been several major shifts in launchpad content and layout maintenance. Refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Faster – Major shifts in SAP Fiori implementation

Target Mappings and Tiles are no longer separate entities. They are combined into Launchpad App Descriptor Items (LADIs).

  • A LADI combines a target mapping with one or more related tiles.
  • LADIs avoids the risk of misalignment when assigning tiles and target mappings.
  • You can choose which tile to display when maintaining your page

Hint: If you have separated your catalogs for tiles versus your catalogs for target mappings, use the technical catalog migration tool in your system conversion to correct your design.

Catalogs follow a 2-level design that is supported and enforced by the tooling. That is:

  • Cross-client technical catalogs that hold original LADIs
  • Client-specific business catalogs the reference LADIs from the technical catalogs.
  • Business catalogs are assigned to (composite or single, SAP or custom) business roles

Technical catalogs can hold many LADIs. They are essentially a container of LADIs.

Business catalogs typically reference a limited number of LADIs, that are assigned to a business role together, such as the smallest Segregation of Duties combination.

Hint: If you have a single-level catalog design, use your system conversion to correct your design. If you have assigned business roles to technical catalogs, use your system conversion to correct your design.

You can use the migration tool for technical catalogs to move your tiles/target mappings to LADIs and align your catalog design to the required 2-level design.

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Technical Catalog Migration – Why and Getting Ready for Migration
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Technical Catalog Migration – How the migration process works

Hint: The technical catalog migration has been further improved in SAP S/4HANA 2025 to make this easier.

The Launchpad Designer is deprecated. You will move to new tooling for managing launchpad content, including:

  • Launchpad App Manager
  • Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific
  • Launchpad Content Aggregator - read-only view of launchpad content
  • Manage Launchpad Spaces
  • Manage Launchpad Pages
  • Overview of Roles, Spaces, and Pages – read-only view of launchpad layouts
  • Launchpad Configuration Parameters
  • Role-based Launchpad Configuration Parameters via transaction /UI2/FLP_PROF_CONF (new with SAP S/4HANA 2025)

All these tools support both single and composite business roles. You will find these tools are assigned to the Fiori Foundation Administration role generated as part of rapid activation task list SAP_FIORI_FOUNDATION_S4 task Generate Fiori Foundation roles.

 

Watchpoints when coming from SAP Fiori in SAP Enterprise Portal

If you are coming from SAP Fiori deployed in SAP Enterprise Portal, there are some additional watchpoints.

1. Select your SAP Build Work Zone edition.

You should compare features available for the central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone standard edition versus advanced edition. If your aim is to create a full business site then advanced edition may suit your needs better.

2. The Universal Work List moves to SAP Fiori app F0862 My Inbox.

Most tasks (work items) will be automatically transitioned.  However, you may want to improve the visualization. If you have configured your Universal Worklist with dynamic columns you will need to explore the extension options in F0862 My Inbox.

3. Pay attention to navigation via OBN

OBN (Object-Based Naivgation) is specific to the SAP Enterprise Portal. Based on customer experiences, you may have some issues getting existing OBN to work in the SAP Fiori launchpad. SAP Fiori launchpad uses intent-based navigation. There are several workarounds already available. For example:

  • SAP Note 3254771 - Failed to resolve object based navigation target in Fiori Launchpad 
  • 3475684 - OBN Navigation Failure within Side Panel App using SAP FIORI System Entry
  • 2934443 - Object Based Navigation in standalone scenario fails
  • 1378659 - NWBC known issues & what to check when opening a ticket

4. Use of LPD_CUST for creating a report hierarchy is still supported. However, you must NOT use LPD_CUST for launchpad content navigation.  

To integrate launchpad content with the SAP Fiori launchpad, you must reconfigure your content using the Launchpad App Manager. Refer to SAP Note 2614740 - Fiori Launchpad Designer - Usage of Application Type "SAP Fiori App using LPD_CUST" in Target Mapping Configuration is Deprecated

 

Reintroducing your upgraded launchpad to your business users

You will find some tips to get you started in the following blog posts:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Organizing your My Home page
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Navigate with confidence

 

Learnings to get you started

Learning Course: Learning the Basics of SAP Fiori

SAP Fiori architecture:

  • Blog SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025
  • Whitepaper SAP Fiori deployment options and system landscape recommendations
  • Whitepaper Moving from Standalone to Embedded Deployment in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA

Learning Videos (how-to guides):

  • Activating SAP Fiori Launchpad Using SAP Fiori Foundation Task List
  • Patching SAP Fiori (SAPUI5)
  • Configuring the SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA
  • Bringing Apps Onto SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • Activating SAP Fiori Content in Custom Business Roles in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA
  • Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles
  • Adapting the UI of List Report Apps with SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA

Transport considerations:

  • Whitepaper SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Rapid Activation Transport Move to Production Strategy

 

What’s behind all these changes in SAP Fiori

SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA reflects the changes over the last 10 years (since 2015) in:

  • business innovations,
  • changes in architecture and technical practices to support business innovations,
  • and in the need for Clean Core approaches to mitigate the increasing speed of change.

Refer to whitepaper: Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

By moving to SAP S/4HANA, your architecture changes:

  • For most customers, you will move your SAP Fiori front-end server from standalone to embedded deployment mode. Refer to SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025 and whitepaper SAP Fiori deployment options and system landscape recommendations
  • You need to consider the impact of cloud services and solutions. For example, you may want to: add the generative AI digital assistant SAP Joule; add a central launchpad via SAP Build Work Zone; consolidate approvals to a unified inbox via SAP Task Center; add process automation through SAP Build; and/or add digital adoption features via SAP WalkMe.

 

Hint: Embedded deployment mode is the most efficient and recommended architecture for SAP S/4HANA. The rapid activation tools and most SAP Fiori support tools either require embedded mode or are optimized for embedded mode.

  • You can transition your current SAP Fiori front-end server to embedded deployment mode. Refer to whitepaper Moving from Standalone to Embedded Deployment in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA.
  • Alternatively, if in SAP Business Suite (SAP ECC) you only use a handful of apps and are willing to accept the loss of user personalizations, you can simply install fresh on embedded mode, and redeploy any custom- or partner-built apps and features.

 

By moving to SAP S/4HANA, the following technical changes apply:

  • The database model changes from being based on ABAP Dictionary tables to ABAP CDS View Entities based on the HANA Database
  • For those coming from Suite on HANA, HANA Live apps were replaced by apps based on ABAP CDS Views.
  • The SAPUI5 version lifts to the latest long-term maintenance version for SAP S/4HANA
  • Programming models for frontend development shift to match the SAPUI5 version – for example the SAP Fiori Flexible Programming Model for SAP Fiori elements
  • The programming model for building & deploying apps changes from SEGW (based on OData V2) to RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP – based on OData V4 and aligned to Cloud Application Programming Model)

 

SAP Fiori elements building blocks improve the consistency of apps for business users and speed the development of custom-built apps by reducing the need for freestyle SAPUI5 apps

 

You will want to gain quick wins from the vast amount of available business content of your target SAP S/4HANA release:

  • A range of new and improved launchpad features become available to you
  • New predefined SAP Fiori apps – as listed SAP Fiori apps reference library

SAP S/4HANA brings more than 3.5K SAP Fiori apps and this is still growing with each SAP S/4HANA release and feature pack.  Plus, another 11.5K classic UIs are provided as pre-configured launchpad content. This content help you give all business users a unified web- and cloud- centric entry point through the SAP Fiori launchpad.

You may have additional business user needs to consider. For example:

  • Central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone
  • Mobile launchpad via SAP Mobile Start
  • Unified inbox via SAP Task Center
  • Advanced innovations, such as SAP Business AI including SAP Joule

Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core. Hint: For on-premise customers considering SAP Business AI, refer to SAP Note 3632703 - Enabling Joule for On-Premise systems

And last but not least you need to consider how you apply Clean Core to reduce future upgrade effort, so you can take on innovations faster.  Especially:

  • The way you extend your SAP S/4HANA solution moves into SAP Fiori. For example, key user adaptations and related SAP Business Roles such as Extensibility Specialist (SAP_ BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC).
  • The way you administer your system moves into SAP Fiori. For example, transport of key user extensions, monitoring of workflows, application jobs, application logs, and managing search models. Quick start by turning on SAP Business Roles such as Administrator. (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR).

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You’ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team.

entry.title: Why clean data is the foundation of enterprise success
entry.content:
Why clean data is the foundation of enterprise success

We’ve all been there: reports that don’t align, systems that refuse to speak the same language, and data that seems to have a mind of its own. It’s frustrating, time-consuming, and costly. Unclean data doesn’t just cause confusion - it multiplies complexity. It clogs business processes, drives up the number of upgrade cycles, and makes every transformation effort harder than it needs to be. And these aren’t just data quality issues - they’re symptoms of a fragmented data foundation that slows progress and limits innovation.

Now imagine a world where every decision is powered by data that just works: accurate, consistent, governed, and seamlessly connected across the enterprise. That’s what clean data makes possible. It’s the quiet engine behind transformation -the unseen force that fuels trust, agility, and innovation.

Clean data turns chaos into clarity. It enables governed, reusable data products built on shared semantics and harmonized master and reference data - so information flows freely across domains, analytics deliver truth instead of noise, and AI scales with confidence. Building on this foundation, the clean core approach takes the next step - transforming data clarity into business agility. It helps organizations unlock the full power of intelligent, connected operations by relying on harmonized, semantically linked data. When processes are standardized around proven best practices and strategic extensions are enabled for differentiation, businesses gain the agility to evolve without complexity.

With SAP Business Suite at the center, this approach keeps systems current, fuels continuous innovation, and paves the way for faster adoption of AI - turning trusted data into a true engine of transformation.

The business power of clean data

Clean data is more than a technical concern - it’s a true business enabler. By embedding clean data practices into the core of your enterprise, you can unlock:

  • Trustworthy decision-making – ensure leaders can rely on accurate, consistent information at every level of the business.
  • Regulatory confidence – meet compliance requirements seamlessly with transparent, auditable data.
  • AI and automation readiness – create the reliable foundation required to scale advanced analytics, automation, and intelligent technologies.
  • Operational excellence – reduce inefficiencies caused by data errors, rework, and duplication, freeing teams to focus on higher-value outcomes.

 

Clean core data whitepaper

That’s why I’m excited to introduce our new Clean core data whitepaper, designed for organizations moving from ERP to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. This paper explores how to make this vision a reality. Inside, you’ll find practical guidance on implementing clean data practices, sustaining them at scale, and unlocking the full potential of your enterprise data.

A sneak preview of what’s inside

Here’s what you’ll find inside:

  • The five pillars of clean core data  - explore the essential dimensions of clean data: strategy, governance, quality, volume efficiency, and protection - each designed to strengthen your enterprise data foundation.
  • A practical measurement framework -  learn how to assess data maturity and governance using KPIs aligned with the RISE with SAP Methodology and dashboard.
  • Operationalizing the data product economy - discover how to leverage SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Master Data Governance to deliver governed, reusable, and high-value data products.
  • Harmonizing SAP and non-SAP data - See how a unified semantic layer ensures interoperability and consistency, while keeping custom extensions decoupled on SAP BTP.
  • Driving seamless upgrades and intelligent insights - gain guidance on reducing infrastructure complexity, minimizing technical debt, and fueling trustworthy AI and analytics with a clean, future-ready data core.

Each chapter of the whitepaper takes you deeper into the journey:

  1. Building a clean core: Overcoming data chaos for a modern, compliant enterprise
  2. Chart the path to your clean data vision: Leverage clean core data to achieve business success
  3. Data framework: Dive deep into the building blocks of clean core data
  4. The cornerstones of a clean core data architecture

 Driving data confidence with the RISE with SAP Methodology

Every successful digital transformation starts with one question: how do we turn data into continuous business value? Within the clean data framework, the answer begins with the RISE with SAP Methodology. It provides a clear roadmap, guiding organizations from identifying data challenges to building, monitoring, and scaling a sustainable clean data strategy. Through automated clean data KPIs, organizations can track the state of their data in real time - across both projects and day-to-day operations. All of this comes together in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard, offering a unified view of data health, performance, and progress toward true data-driven agility.

Ready to take the first step?

Clean data is not a one-time project - it’s a journey and a discipline. The first step is to explore the Whitepaper on clean data and see how organizations can establish a foundation for smarter decisions, efficient operations, and long-term resilience.

👉 Download the Clean core data whitepaper

entry.title: Should you wait until FPS1 is available before implementing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025?
entry.content:
Hello, and thanks for spending some time reading this blog post! As a member of the SAP S/4HANA RIG (Regional Implementation Group), we share our collective insights and knowledge with the broader SAP community through blog posts and SAP Learning courses. We’ve published over 700 blogs and delivered numerous courses to help you navigate the world of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Today, I want to address a commonly asked question we have received since the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025: Should customers wait until FPS1 is available before implementing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025?

Let’s clear the air: Customers who want to take advantage of a new S/4HANA release immediately can and should install FPS00. Remember, SAP S/4HANA was first launched in 2015. Therefore, SAP S/4HANA is a mature solution. Additionally, in the latest releases, SAP has emphasized refinement and enhancements over introducing radical changes, which, in the past, could have been the root cause of errors when implementing the initial stack.

Moreover, our commitment to quality is robust. In addition to rigorous testing by our development team, we actively involve customers and partners in the SAP S/4HANA Beta program with every release. This initiative enables the real-world testing of new features and the evaluation of transition paths, such as new implementations and upgrades. Throughout the program, we received no reports that would jeopardize product stability. In fact, survey results from participants supported the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025 based on their testing experiences.

I'd like to share some good news about SAP Fiori – the primary user experience of SAP S/4HANA - and SAPUI5 - the User Interface (UI) framework of SAP Fiori.  

  • In the past, when SAP released a new version of SAP S/4HANA, the initial release (FPS0) was introduced with a SAPUI5 innovation version, which was not intended to be a long-term version. For this reason, customers often preferred to wait for the SAPUI5 long-term maintenance version, released with a later update (FPS01), before going live with SAP S/4HANA in their production environment.

 

  • Starting with SAP S/4HANA 2025, SAPUI5 is released on the long-term maintenance version right from the initial release (FPS0). This means you can confidently use the user experience in production from day one, minimizing disruptions and ensuring easier support. For more information, refer to the following SAP Notes: 2217489 - Maintenance and Update Strategy for SAP Fiori Front-End Server and 3636986 - SAPUI5 maintenance strategy for SAP_UI and the accompanying SAP blog post SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025. 

 

  • As usual, it’s recommended that you start with the latest available patch level of your SAPUI5 version. For SAP S/4HANA 2025, the SAPUI5 version is SAPUI5 1.136.  Your technical team can refer to our new learning video Patching SAP Fiori (SAPUI5) to learn how to apply patches quickly and easily.  You can find the latest available patch level at the SAPUI5 Versions Maintenance Status page.

 

Of course, there are valid reasons why some customers may want to wait for a future FPS. Here are two scenarios that might justify pausing.

  • Add-Ons Compatibility: If you rely on Partner add-ons (Solution extensions) or third-party add-ons that are not currently compatible with SAP S/4HANA 2025, it’s crucial to engage with the add-on vendors to understand when they will be compatible. It may take a few months, so it could be wise to wait for FPS1 before proceeding.

 

  • Future Innovations: Each FPS comes packed with new innovations. If there’s a specific feature planned for FPS1 that can add significant value to your business, it might make sense to wait until that functionality is available. To find planned features, you can check the Road Map Explorer.

In conclusion, while there might be reasons to consider waiting, the overall landscape for SAP S/4HANA 2025 is looking promising. If you decide to forge ahead, you can do so with confidence in the maturity and robustness of the solution.

If you are considering moving to SAP S/4HANA 2025 and would like SAP support with product-related issues and product-related questions, you can apply to our SAP S/4HANA Customer Care program, following the instructions described here: Cloud Private Edition - Customer Care.

Thank you for reading, and I encourage everyone to embrace the latest innovations that come with SAP S/4HANA!. If you find this blog useful, please consider giving it a "like" or sharing it. I’d love to hear your thoughts and feedback, so feel free to leave a comment. If you have any questions, just drop them in the Q&A section with the tags SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. We'll try to get back to you as soon as we can.


Thanks,

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG team.

entry.title: Launch of RISE with SAP Methodology & Experience Certification for Senior Roles

You already know how to implement ERP / ECC and have a successful track record of driving such implementations? Add RISE with SAP methodology—the key to ERP Cloud projects—and you’re fully equipped for the certification.
